author: djrtwo
content:
[probably not the best place to discuss dates.]

depending on how medalla falls in the next few days, we may or may not do another large public testnet

As for other items. There are a number of parallel nets to be built and tested for stress testing, practicing genesis, etc <-- on all of those we could test 5.1

And for mainnet, there will be a "genesis delay" of somewhere between 4 and 7 days. If any issues in discovery happened on the early end of that, we could go in and debug before the date.
Probably not optimal to have mainnet not have the same discovery version as a "final" testnet, but I also don't particularly want to do an in flight discovery upgrade if we can avoid it

author: .fjl
content: Understood. In other news: the topic index simulation project is going very well. We now have an implementation of most of the protocol in PeerSim, a discrete event simulator written in Java.

author: .fjl
content: The existing impl. could not be reused because these kinds of simulators want you to use their API for scheduling events such as message sends and timers.

author: .fjl
content: Our baseline result by now is that the DHT is indeed converging, but we had already kind of confirmed that with the eth2 testnets I guess.

author: .fjl
content: The team is currently implementing a couple different algorithms for the topic index and then we'll be able to run those and get network-wide event traces from the simulation.

author: djrtwo
content:
>  DHT is indeed converging
can you define converging here?

author: .fjl
content: Someone in the team is also working on a loader for the DHT crawler JSON dump format that we produce using go-ethereum.

author: .fjl
content: By converging, I mean that the nodes form a healthy network without islands using the basic, Kademlia-like DHT protocol that we have.

content: got it

author: .fjl
content: The algo in the spec doesn't really work, which is why we're not using it (in eth2). They had a couple ideas for improving it, they're in the spec issue tracker.

author: .fjl
content: We're looking to implement those ideas, basically

author: .fjl
content: I'm excited about it, not just for eth2, but also because figuring out decentralized service discovery would be a genuine improvement for 'future internet' purposes.
